description: From Middle English thinne, thünne, thenne, from Old English þynne, from Proto-West Germanic *þunnī, from Proto-Germanic *þunnuz (“thin”) – compare *þanjaną (“to stretch, spread out”) – from Proto-Indo-European *ténh₂us (“thin”), from *ten- (“to stretch”).

Cognate with German dünn, Dutch dun, West Frisian tin, Icelandic þunnur, Danish tynd, Swedish tunn, Latin tenuis, Irish tanaí, Welsh tenau, Latvian tievs, Sanskrit तनु (tanú, “thin”), Persian تنگ‎ (tang, “narrow”). Doublet of tenuis. Also related to tenuous.

entries.meaning: Having little thickness or extent from one surface to its opposite.
examples: thin plate of metal;  thin paper;  thin board;  thin covering

entries.meaning: Very narrow in all diameters; having a cross section that is small in all directions.
Having little body fat or flesh; slim; slender; lean; gaunt.
Of low viscosity or low specific gravity.
Scarce; not close, crowded, or numerous; not filling the space.
examples: The trees of a forest are thin; the corn or grass is thin.

entries.meaning: (golf) Describing a poorly played golf shot where the ball is struck by the bottom part of the club head. See fat, shank, toe.
Lacking body or volume; small; feeble; not full.
examples: thin, hollow sounds, and lamentable screams

entries.meaning: Slight; small; slender; flimsy; superficial; inadequate; not sufficient for a covering.
(aviation) Of a route: relatively little used.
examples: In short, we previously found that thin routes benefit from an increase in competition in the Spanish airline market when considering routes that were monopoly routes in 2001.

entries.meaning: Poor; scanty; without money or success.
examples: Like their friends the "draggers," the "hoisters" or shoplifters are having a thin time these days,  […]

adverbs.description: thin (comparative more thin, superlative most thin)

entries.meaning: Not thickly or closely; in a scattered state.
(philately) A loss or tearing of paper from the back of a stamp, although not sufficient to create a complete hole.
Any food produced or served in thin slices.

verbs.description: thin (third-person singular simple present thins, present participle thinning, simple past and past participle thinned)

examples: The crowds thinned after the procession had passed: there was nothing more to see.

entries.meaning: To remove some plants or parts of plants in order to improve the growth of what remains.
